Thanks Ron you saved me alot of typing LOL=


You are correct RJ, if you are still in the stage of how and why and look=
ing for "proof" it is better to do experiments and sharing the way you desc=
ribe. Go for it.

And Ron already knows me well. I am a little beyond carin=
g how or why it works, or even asking spirits questions. I just record thie=
r chatter, document for my own learning, and share with a few friends or pe=
rsons its meant for privately. Once in a while I post samples for others wh=
o are curious about the different methods being used or new to the subject.=
 

I never expect anyone to hear anything as I do, its a nice surprise when=
 someone does =3D)

Good luck!

Misty

> I know what you mean Misty - it does seem tha=
t
> interpretations are often varied.=A0 I am thinking that the
> best way =
to make progress is to get an audio sample that you
> think is most represe=
ntative of a given approach's
> effectiveness, and send that privately to s=
everal people.=A0
> Name the file something innocuous (like File1) and
> do=
n';t tell the people you send it to what you think you
> hear.=A0 Also, ask=
 the people not to discuss the file with
> anyone else, and have them send =
what they think they hear
> directly back to you,rather than posting the re=
sults in a
> forum or group.
> 
> I think that kind of test is helpful, sin=
ce it seems to me
> that once someone tells me what the audio clip sounds l=
ike,
> then it's hard for me to hear anything else in it.=A0
> But,that cou=
ld be influencing my interpretation (like
> someone pointing to a cloud, te=
lling me its a horse, and
> then I have trouble NOT seeing a horse) ,so it'=
s better
> to listen before it is suggested to me what i should be
> hearin=
g.
> 
> This way, I think the most progress can be made, because if
> peopl=
e just keep confirming what we think we hear, and it
> turns out it's just =
noise that we are forcing an
> interpretation into, we won't be making prog=
ress (though
> it might make us feel good to believe that we're being
> suc=
cessful).=A0 Getting negative feedback to one's
> approach is not as fun, a=
nd might feel like some
> non-believer is trying to debunk us.=A0 But, real=
ly, that can
> be the best feedback for progress, since it helps us to
> ch=
ange tactics when our current approach is not effective,
> rather than cont=
inuing down an ineffective path, getting
> accolades from friends, but miss=
ing out on other paths that
> might show more promise,.
>

 <<A href="http://us.mc01g.mail.yahoo.com/mc/compose?to=ronriko%40yahoo.com" target=_blank rel=nofollow ymailto="mailto:ronriko%40yahoo.com">ronriko@yahoo. com</A>><BR>> Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] New Water EVP<BR>> To: <A href="http://us.mc01g.mail.yahoo.com/mc/compose?to=EVP-ITC%40yahoogroups.com" target=_blank rel=nofollow ymailto="mailto:EVP-ITC%40yahoogroups.com">EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com</A><BR>> Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2009, 12:04 PM<BR>> Hello RJ  You make good points here.  I had to re look at<BR>> the purpose of the group to see if this was a scientific<BR>> research group or other.  It looks like it is in the<BR>> "or other" category.  I do believe there are<BR>> strictly research groups around that can apply the rules of<BR>> scientific testing.  More in the hobbyist or enthusiast<BR>> mode?<BR>>  <BR>> One  of the reasons I joined this group is because
 I<BR>> appreciate members like Misty for posting their work and<BR>> not having to do so under some scientific<BR>> methodology.   That, I think, would hinder innovation,<BR>> testing, sharing and even enjoyment of what we do here. <BR>> And, again, it is not the stated purpose of this<BR>> group.  Doubters and debunkers certainly have a place in<BR>> this non-scientific arena, but here I hope to see posts from<BR>> people who are not afraid to try a technique and then share<BR>> it with others.  I was looking for your posts with the<BR>> group here...do you have any?  I do not mean that as a<BR>> challenge...  ymailto="mailto:EVP-ITC%40yahoogroups.com">EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com</A><BR>> Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2009, 8:15 AM<BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> <BR>> I know what you mean Misty - it does seem that<BR>> interpretations are often varied.  I am thinking that the<BR>> best way to make progress is to get an audio sample that you<BR>> think is most representative of a given approach's<BR>> effectiveness, and send that privately to several people. <BR>> Name the file something innocuous (like File1) and<BR>> don';t tell the people you send it to what you think you<BR>> hear.  Also, ask the people not to discuss the file with<BR>> anyone else, and have them send what they think they hear<BR>> directly back to you,rather than posting the results in a<BR>> forum or group.<BR>> <BR>> I think that kind of test is helpful, since it seems to
 me<BR>> that once someone tells me what the audio clip sounds like,<BR>> then it's hard for me to hear anything else in it. <BR>> But,that could be influencing my interpretation (like<BR>> someone pointing to a cloud, telling me its a horse, and<BR>> then I have trouble NOT seeing a horse) ,so it's better<BR>> to listen before it is suggested to me what i should be<BR>> hearing.<BR>> <BR>> This way, I think the most progress can be made, because if<BR>> people just keep confirming what we think we hear, and it<BR>> turns out it's just noise that we are forcing an<BR>> interpretation into, we won't be making progress (though<BR>> it might make us feel good to believe that we're being<BR>> successful).  Getting negative feedback to one's<BR>> approach is not as fun, and might feel like some<BR>> non-believer is trying to debunk us.  But, really, that can<BR>> be the best feedback for
